questions.question: What is the most commonly fractured bone in cases of basilar skull fractures?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Temporal bone Explanation: The temporal bone is the most commonly fractured in basilar skull fractures. These fractures can lead to serious complications, including damage to cranial nerves VII (facial nerve) and VIII (vestibulocochlear nerve) and the carotid artery, as well as potential cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks. Thickness of skull bones Male Female Frontal 7.8 mm 8.6 mm Parietal 9.6 mm 10.1 mm Occipital 10.1 mm 10 mm Temporal 6 mm 6 mm Temporal bone fracture Longitudinal Temporal Bone Fracture Transverse Temporal Bone Fracture The most common type (70-90% of temporal bone fractures). Runs parallel to the long axis of the petrous temporal bone. Otic Capsule is spared. Conductive hearing loss due to ossicle involvement and tympanic membrane involvement. Facial nerve involvement occurs in about 25% of cases. Less common (10-30% of temporal bone fractures). Extends perpendicular to the petrous temporal bone's long axis. Otic Capsule is involved, leading to sensorineural hearing loss. Ossicles and tympanic membranes are generally unaffected. Higher incidence of facial nerve involvement. Occipital bone ( Option B ), Sphenoid bone ( Option C ), Frontal bone ( Option D ): While the occipital, sphenoid, and frontal bones can be involved in basilar skull fractures, they are not as commonly fractured as the temporal bone. Their occurrences are significantly less frequent compared to fractures of the temporal bone. Reference: Basilar Skull Fractures Skull Thickness Cranial Vault Thickness Longitudinal vs transverse petrous temporal bone fracture Temporal Fracture

questions.question: In which of the following scenarios is a diastatic skull fracture most likely to occur?

options.A: An adult hit by a broad surface object
options.B: A child with increased intracranial pressure
options.C: A teenager experiencing a sports-related injury
options.D: An elderly person falling onto their buttocks

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) A child with increased intracranial pressure Explanation: Fissured Fracture (Linear Fracture) Diastatic Fracture (Sutural Fracture) The most common skull fracture accounts for about 70% of cases. Linear cracks may involve the vertex or skull base. It can affect the full thickness of the bone or just the inner/outer layers. The fracture line is irregular and fine, sometimes hard to detect on X-rays. It runs parallel to the compressive force. No depression of bone fragments. Involves the separation of cranial sutures. More common in children. Often occurs with other skull fractures, especially fissured fractures. Commonly seen at the sagittal suture. Causes: Impact against broad surfaces (e.g., falls or road traffic accidents). (Option A ruled out) Falls on feet or buttocks, transmitting force upwards. (Option D ruled out) Causes: Blunt trauma to the head. Increased intracranial pressure leads to suture separation. (Option B) Narrow fissure skull fracture A teenager experiencing a sports-related injury (Option C): Sports-related injuries typically do not involve sutural separation, which is specific to diastatic fractures.

questions.question: A 32 year old male is brought to the emergency after sustaining a gunshot wound to the head during a robbery. The bullet trajectory is reported as oblique. Which type of skull fracture is most commonly associated with this presentation?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Gutter fracture Explanation: Depressed Fracture Comminuted Fracture Gutter Fracture Occurs when a fragment of the skull is pushed inward towards the brain. Caused by blows from heavy objects with a small surface (e.g., hammers, bricks). (Option A ruled out) The shape of the depressed area may resemble the object that caused the injury. Variants: Elevated Fracture : One end of the fractured fragment is raised above the skull, while the other is pushed inward. Caused by sharp objects like an axe. (Option D ruled out) Pond Fracture : Seen in infants, this smooth depression occurs without a fracture line, resembling a dent in a ping-pong ball. Caused by obstetrics forceps blade. Involves multiple intersecting fracture lines, breaking the bone into several fragments. Caused by high-impact trauma (e.g., vehicular accidents, crushing injuries). (Option C ruled

questions.question: A “motorcyclist fracture," typically results from what type of impact?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Side impact Explanation: Ring Fracture Motorcyclist Fracture (Hinge Fracture) Encircles the foramen magnum at the skull base. Runs from the sella turcica to the petrous ridges and posterior fossa. It can extend to the middle ear and roof of the nose. Transverse fracture at the skull base, splitting it and creating a "hinge" - nodding face sign . It extends from one petrous ridge across the sella turcica to the other petrous ridge. Caused by: (Option B, C and D ruled out) Falls landing on feet/buttocks (force transmitted through the spine). Heavy blows to the top of the skull/ vertex. Twisting of the head on the spine. Blows to the occiput or chin. Often caused by side impacts . (Option A) Ring fracture Hinge fracture

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with facial trauma after being struck in the eye during a sports accident. Which radiographic finding is most indicative of a blowout fracture of the orbit?

options.D: Circular crack around the skull base

questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Teardrop sign Explanation: Blowout fracture is a fracture of the bony orbit (eye socket) resulting from blunt trauma to the eye. It causes fractures to the medial wall and floor of the orbit. The teardrop sign is a significant radiographic finding in blowout fractures , indicating the herniation of orbital soft tissues, such as fat and muscles, into the maxillary sinus. This often leads to pain, restricted eye movements and diplopia. Blowout fracture of right orbit showing Teardrop sign Spider web-like pattern on X-ray (Option A): The spider web-like pattern on an X-ray is characteristic of comminuted fractures , which involve multiple fracture lines creating a fragmented appearance. Ping-pong ball dent appearance (Option B): The ping-pong ball dent appearance is associated with pond fractures, which occur in infants and young children. This type of fracture is characterised by a smooth, concave indentation in the skull without a distinct fracture line. Circular crack around the skull base (Option D): A circular crack around the skull base is indicative of a ring fracture, which encircles the foramen magnum and is associated with severe trauma.

questions.question: A 45 year old woman falls and strikes the back of her head on the ground. Upon examination, she exhibits signs of a contrecoup injury affecting the frontal lobe. Which of the following statements about her injury is incorrect? region.

options.A: The injury results from the brain striking the frontal skull after an initial impact on the occipital
options.B: Contrecoup injuries are commonly associated with RTAs.
options.C: Contrecoup injuries primarily affect the areas directly beneath the point of impact.
options.D: The rotational forces during the fall could contribute to the contrecoup mechanism.

questions.explanation: impact. Correct Answer: C) Contrecoup injuries primarily affect the areas directly beneath the point of impact. Explanation: Coup injuries primarily affect the areas directly beneath the point of impact, while contrecoup injuries affect the side opposite the impact. Coup vs. Contrecoup Injuries Features Coup Contrecoup Definition Brain injury directly beneath the point of impact. Brain injury on the side opposite the impact. Mechanism Caused by direct impact force. Occurs when a moving head is suddenly decelerated by hitting a firm surface eg. striking the head on the ground after a fall during RTAs. (Option B ruled out) Occurrence More common when a moving object strikes the head. Common in falls or blows to a stationary head. Common scenarios Common in moving head striking an object, e.g., hitting a car dashboard in an accident. Seen in falls, where the head hits the ground or an unyielding surface, causing injury on the opposite side of the impact. Organs involved It can be seen in the brain, heart, spleen and lungs. (More commonly in the brain) Theories of Contrecoup Injuries: Shear Strain Theory (Holbourn): Brain particles are pulled apart due to rotational forces. (Option D ruled out) Vacuum Theory: A vacuum or cavity forms in the cranial cavity, exerting suction on the brain opposite the point of impact, causing damage. Deceleration Theory: Sudden arrest of the head causes the brain to strike the skull at the opposite pole of impact. Common scenarios: Occipital impact: Produces frontal contrecoup injury due to brain displacement against the frontal lobes. (Option A ruled out) Temporal or parietal impact: Results in contralateral contrecoup injury on the opposite side of the brain. Top of the head impact: Can cause ventral surface contusion of the cerebral hemisphere. Frontal region impact: May not produce occipital contrecoup injury due to the smooth internal surface of the posterior cranial fossa Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 192, 193 Organs affected

questions.question: In the context of intracranial haemorrhages, which of the following statements accurately describes the relationship between the layers of the cranial anatomy and the associated blood vessels?

options.A: The epidural space contains bridging veins.
options.B: The subdural space is located between the pia mater and the arachnoid mater.
options.C: The subarachnoid space contains arteries of the circle of Willis.
options.D: The middle meningeal artery is located between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) The subarachnoid space contains arteries of the circle of Willis Explanation: The subarachnoid space is situated between the arachnoid mater and pia mater and contains major arteries, including those of the circle of Willis. This space is usually filled with clear, colourless cerebrospinal fluid. Head trauma or rupture of an intracranial aneurysm causes a subarachnoid haemorrhage (bleeding in the subarachnoid space). The most common specific locations of intracranial aneurysms are at the middle cerebral artery bifurcation and along the anterior communicating artery. Meningeal layers Intracranial haemorrhages The first layer is the skull vault (cranium), followed by the dura mater, arachnoid mater, pia mater, and brain tissue (cerebrum). The space between the skull and dura contains the middle meningeal artery. The middle meningeal artery is most prominent at the pterion, the point where the frontal, parietal, sphenoid, and temporal bones meet. Space Location Blood vessel involved Epidural Space Between the skull vault and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to epidural hematoma. Middle meningeal artery (Option D ruled out) Subdural Space Between the arachnoid and dura mater. The collection of blood here leads to subdural hematoma. (Option B ruled out) Bridging veins (which drain into the dural venous sinus) (Option A ruled out) Subarachnoid Space Between the arachnoid and pia mater Arteries of the circle of Willis (Middle cerebral artery, Anterior communicating artery -most commonly) (Option C)

questions.question: A 25 year old man is brought to the ED after a fall from a height. He was unconscious upon arrival, and a CT scan was done which revealed the following. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

options.B: Rupture of the middle meningeal artery

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Rupture of the middle meningeal artery Explanation: The CT scan of the patient showing a biconvex accumulation of blood between the skull and dura mater after a fall confirms the diagnosis of EDH. EDH is primarily caused by trauma leading to the rupture of the middle meningeal artery. questions.question: A forensic pathologist examines a body that has suffered extensive thermal injury. Which of the following characteristics would most likely indicate the presence of a heat hematoma as a postmortem finding?

options.B: Reddish brown discolouration of the hematoma
options.D: Honeycomb appearance of a blood clot

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Honeycomb appearance of a blood clot Explanation: The honeycomb appearance of a blood clot is indicative of a heat hematoma, which is a specific postmortem finding associated with thermal injuries. A heat hematoma resembles an extradural haemorrhage in appearance and therefore needs to be differentiated from it. Features Extradural Haematoma Heat Haematoma Cause Trauma to the skull. Exposure of the head to intense heat leads to charring. (Option C ruled out) Mechanism Most commonly due to rupture of the meningeal artery Shrinkage of meninges and brain, causing brain tissue to ooze out. Location Usually adjacent to Sylvian fissure and limited due to dural attachments at the suture line. Anywhere, usually bilateral. Distribution Localised Diffuse Trauma signs Signs of blunt force trauma are present. Signs of blunt force trauma are absent. Blood clot A rubbery, reddish-purple blood clot is seen. Discoid shape. A soft, friable clot of light chocolate colour is seen. (Option B ruled out) Honeycomb appearance, evenly distributed or sickle-shaped. (Option C) Carboxyhemoglobin Absent Present (Option A ruled out) Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Page 196, 197, 248, 249, 250 Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 243

questions.question: A 65 year old woman presents to the emergency department with confusion and headache that developed gradually over the past two weeks after a minor fall. A CT scan reveals an isodense lesion along the cerebral convexities. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Subacute Subdural Hemorrhage Explanation: The gradual onset of symptoms and isodense appearance on CT are characteristic of subacute subdural haemorrhage, typically occurring days to weeks after injury. questions.question: A 50 y/o man is found unconscious in his home after complaining of severe headache. A CT of the patient is given below. His medical history is significant for hypertension and smoking. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Ruptured berry aneurysm Explanation: The CT scan shows evidence of subarachnoid haemorrhage, which is characterised by bleeding into the space between the brain and the meninges. It shows a classical star sign . The most common cause of subarachnoid haemorrhage is a ruptured aneurysm ,

questions.question: A retired boxer presents with a gradual decline in his coordination, memory, and speech over the past few years. His wife reports personality changes, including paranoia and social withdrawal. O/E, he displays dysarthria and broad-based gait. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Dementia pugilistica Explanation: The patient’s history of repeated head trauma (boxing), along with symptoms like incoordination, memory loss, personality changes, dysarthria and broad-based gait, is characteristic of punch-drunk syndrome (dementia pugilistica) . Punch-Drunk Syndrome: Also known as dementia pugilistica or boxer's encephalopathy , it results from repeated cerebral concussions, typically in boxers. Signs and Symptoms: Deterioration of speed and reflexes Incoordination Personality changes (social instability, paranoia, delusions) Memory loss (progressing to dementia) Parkinsonian signs : Ataxia or intention tremors Shuffling, broad-based gait Dysarthria (difficulty speaking) Autopsy findings: Chronic subdural haematoma (SDH) Attenuation of the corpus callosum Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) Cortical atrophy Parkinson's disease (Option A) : Although Parkinson's disease shares some features like tremors and gait disturbances, this patient has a history of boxing and repeated head trauma, which makes punch-drunk syndrome more likely. Alzheimer's disease (Option B) is primarily associated with memory loss and cognitive decline but the history of boxing and gait disturbances differentiate punch drunk syndrome from it. Multiple sclerosis (Option D) can cause motor and cognitive symptoms but is less likely given the patient's history and specific symptoms linked to repeated head trauma. Reference: Review of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 3rd Edition, Page 239

questions.question: A 65 year old man with a history of hypertension presents to the ED with a sudden onset of weakness in his right arm and leg. He also complains of a severe headache and nausea. On examination, he has a decreased level of consciousness and right-sided hemiparesis. A CT scan shows a hyperdense lesion in the left basal ganglia. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Hypertensive intracerebral haemorrhage Explanation: The patient has a history of hypertension and the CT findings (hyperdense lesion in the basal ganglia) are typical of hypertensive ICH, which commonly affects the basal ganglia. Putamen is the most common site of hypertensive bleeding. Intracerebral Haemorrhage (ICH): ICH refers to bleeding within the brain parenchyma, distinct from surface bleeding. Causes of ICH: The most common cause is hypertension. Clinical Features: Sudden onset of focal neurological deficit Decreased consciousness Signs of raised intracranial pressure (vomiting, headache) Contralateral hemiparesis Seizures are rare Diagnosis: CT scan : ICH appears as a hyperdense lesion Comparison with other haemorrhages: EDH: Biconvex, lenticular (Option A ruled out) SDH: Crescentic (Option D ruled out) SAH: Hyperdense along the falx and basilar cisterns (Option B ruled out) EDH SDH SAH
